meanings.definition: A person who is lazy or unreliable.
meanings.sent1: My brother is such a skell, always sleeping in and never helping out.
meanings.sent2: The skell didn't show up for work again, causing trouble for everyone.
meanings.sent3: The skell tried to blame his laziness on his pet turtle, which was quite amusing.
meanings.sent4: She was a skell in disguise, pretending to work while actually doing nothing.
meanings.sent5: The image of a skell lounging on a hammock all day stuck in my mind.

meanings.sent1: I tend to skell when it comes to doing chores around the house.
meanings.sent2: He would always skell his duties and leave them for others to complete.
meanings.sent3: The cat decided to skell its job of catching mice and instead napped in the sun.
meanings.sent4: The student tried to skell his homework by claiming the dog ate it.
meanings.sent5: The clouds seemed to skell their duty of bringing rain to the parched land.

meanings.sent1: The con artist tried to skell unsuspecting tourists out of their money.
meanings.sent2: She managed to skell her way into getting a free meal at the restaurant.
meanings.sent3: The magician skelled the audience with his disappearing act, leaving them amazed.
meanings.sent4: The shady salesman skelled customers by selling them fake products.
meanings.sent5: The fox skelled the rabbit by pretending to be its friend before pouncing.
